title: I've applied for the audition, I can sing, rap and dance, but I'm African, is it possible for me to be a Kpop idol? - Quora

response.answer_text: As an African myself, you can audition if you want. But just to let you know, the chances are very slim for international trainees. There are some obstacles to watch out for: Racism: Korean and international netizens are known to be quite controversial when it comes to K-pop (in other words, flat out racist). K-pop netizens are used to seeing pale, clean faces, small faces, and sharp noses. To them, seeing a dark or tanned-skin idol would kinda collapse the whole Korean beauty standard. Which leads us to: Bullying: Looking back from what I have stated earlier, this will easily count as bullying and discrimination. In fact, K-pop artists such as Sulli from f(x) committed suicide due to bullying. People with almost no Asian ethnicity will definitely find the experience 10 times worse than the average K-pop trainee. In addition, trainees will also have to deal with paying a large debt for housing (and paying the company), as well as sasaengs (obsessed K-fans), and not getting the chance to debut after the course of a couple of years. If you do want to become an artist, it is easier to do so in your own country since you can also be as famous worldwide in the right record (Atlantic, Interscope, Republic, etc.). Now I’m not saying to not audition for a Korean company, but if your heart is sought out on this job, YOU GO GIRL! I wish you the best, and if you don’t get in, there are other companies to try out for. Here are some suggestions: Fantagio EntertainmentWoolim EntertainmentWM EntertainmentRainbowbridge World EntertainmentBlockberry Creative
